title: Newton's First Law Challenge

questions.question: In the 'The Stubbornness of Objects' module, it is mentioned that a hockey puck sliding on ice won't stop on its own in space. Why is this?
options: Because there is no net external force like friction to change its motion
Because the puck has a high engine force
Because the puck's velocity is increasing
questions.explanation: According to the Law of Inertia, an object in motion stays in motion at a constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force. In space, the lack of friction (摩擦力) means there is no force to stop the puck's motion.

questions.question: Looking at 'The Net Force Equation', if we observe that an object's velocity (v) is constant and not changing, what must be true about ΣF?
options: ΣF must be greater than zero
ΣF depends on the weight of the object
questions.explanation: The formula ΣF = 0 ⮕ v = constant states that when the net force is zero, the velocity remains constant. If the velocity isn't changing, the sum of all external forces acting on that object must be zero.

questions.question: A book is sitting perfectly still on a table. Based on the concept that objects 'want' to keep doing what they are doing, which statement is correct?
questions.explanation: This is True. Newton's First Law applies to objects at rest just as much as objects in motion. The 'stubbornness' (inertia) of the book means it will remain at rest until a net external force, like a push, acts on it.

questions.question: Scenario: A spacecraft is traveling through a void at 10,000 m/s. If the engines are turned off and there is zero friction or gravity, what happens to the spacecraft's speed?
options: It will slowly come to a stop
It will continue at exactly 10,000 m/s indefinitely
It will immediately drop to zero
It will speed up because there is no air resistance
questions.explanation: This applies the 'key insight' that forces change motion, they don't maintain it. Without friction or engine force, the net force ΣF is zero, so the velocity (v) remains a constant 10,000 m/s as per the Law of Inertia.

questions.question: If a car is moving at a constant speed of 60 km/h in a straight line, but the engine is clearly applying a forward force, how can ΣF = 0 be true?
options: The engine force is not a real force
The car is actually accelerating slightly
Friction and air resistance are equal and opposite to the engine force
Newton's Law only applies to objects at rest
questions.explanation: For velocity to be constant (v = constant), the net force (ΣF) must be zero. The forward force from the engine is balanced out by external forces like friction (摩擦力), resulting in a net force of zero.

quiz_strategy: The questions transition from basic conceptual definitions found in 'The Stubbornness of Objects' to the mathematical application of the symbols in 'The Net Force Equation'. I included a scenario-based question to challenge the common misconception that a force is needed to maintain motion, specifically referencing the 'key insight' from the text module.
